Calligraphy in clerical-script style, 118 columns. Fragment. Transcribed by

Dunhuang caves. Removed in 1910 for Beijing. Ended up in theFanjiang Ge凡將閣hall ofLi Shengduo (Muzhai)李盛鐸 (木齋 )ofDehua德化. After Li Shengduo died, the work was purchased in 1947 (dinghai) byZhang Guchu張谷雛(1890-1968; i.e., Zhang Hong, a Cantonese painter working in an art publishing firm in the 1930s) [recorded in his "Jichuanan suo cang Dunhuang shishi tulu" 寄傳庵所藏敦煌石室圖案 manuscript copy].Ye Gongchuo葉恭綽was one of the few people to see this work when it was in Li Shengduo's collection. After it went to Zhang Guchu,it was viewed byHuang Binhong黃賓虹and Ye. When Rao Zongyi wrote about this piece, it was still in Zhang Guchu's collection. In 1960, it became part of the Peng family collection in Hong Kong, and it entered the John B. Elliott coll. in 1985.
Ye Gongchuo葉恭綽(1880-ca. 1968; t. Yufu, Yuhu, Yufu; h. Xia-an, Shujuyuan).
